lineChart.title: What?
content: A line chart or line graph is a type of chart which displays information as a series of data points called 'markers' connected by straight line segments. It is a basic type of chart common in many fields. Referenced from Wikipedia

lineChart.title: When?
content: Data changes over time, e.g. stock prices / daily visitors of the site / yearly changes in any kind of subjects.
Tendencies based on periodic values, e.g. temporatues / ages / distance in mathematical model.

barChart.title: What?
content: A bar chart or bar graph is a chart or graph that presents categorical data with rectangular bars with heights or lengths proportional to the values that they represent. The bars can be plotted vertically or horizontally. A vertical bar chart is sometimes called a line graph.

A bar graph shows comparisons among discrete categories. One axis of the chart shows the specific categories being compared, and the other axis represents a measured value. Some bar graphs present bars clustered in groups of more than one, showing the values of more than one measured variable.

barChart.title: When?
content: Comparing categorical data such as months, years, size, region ... etc.
Categories are usually qualitative.

barChart.title: How?
content: Can be easily compared by the height of the bar (when y-axis represents the value of the category) or the width of the bar (when x-axis represents the value of the category)
Can be arranged in orders from the highest to the lowest vice-versa.
When label is too long to display or the number of categories is large (over 10 might be a threshold), it is recommended to make horizontal bar chart.
Scales can be changed from linear to logarithmic if quantity of different categories have huge difference.

donutChart.title: What?
content: A donut chart is a variant of the pie chart, with a blank center allowing for additional information about the data as a whole to be included. Donut charts are similar to pie charts in that their aim is to illustrate proportions. This type of circular graph can support multiple statistics at once and it provides a better data intensity ratio to standard pie charts. It does not have to contain information in the center. Referenced from Wikipedia

donutChart.title: When?
content: Less data categories comparison.
Huge value variation.
Human eye loves circular visual effect which gives us harmony.
Generally, it can be replaced by histogram / bar chart ... etc.

donutChart.title: How?
content: Keep the number of slices to minimum.
Don't use 3D pie chart / donut chart.
When data values are too close to compare, consider using bar chart or histogram.
Don't put legends in the section of the donut chart, put it outside.

heatMap.title: What?
content: A heat map is a graphical representation of data where the individual values contained in a matrix are represented as colors. "Heat map" is a newer term but shading matrices have existed for over a century. Referenced from Wikipedia

heatMap.title: Which?
content: Biology heat maps are typically used in molecular biology to represent the level of expression of many genes across a number of comparable samples (e.g. cells in different states, samples from different patients) as they are obtained from DNA microarrays.
The tree map is a 2D hierarchical partitioning of data that visually resembles a heat map.
A mosaic plot is a tiled heat map for representing a two-way or higher-way table of data.

heatMap.title: When?
content: Visualizing 2D structured data arrays with elements are quantitative, e.g. visualizing Gaussian-Distribution mathematical model or human population density in worldwide.
Not only 2D structured data arrays can be used with heat map, it can also be visualizing different region's result such as visualizing the election results in U.S. map.

heatMap.title: How?
content:
Select color scheme properly depends on which kind of data you are visualizing:
Discrete categories can use various colors to visualize.
Same categories with levels of different quantitative values, you can use monochromatic color varying with shades.
Each numerical range between different shade should be even.
Heat map doesn't necessarily need to draw each elements in square or a 2D matrix. For instance, visualizing regions with different shades in a map.

pictogramChart.title: What?
content: A pictogram, or so-called pictograph is an Ideogram that conveys its meaning through its pictorial resemblance to a physical object.

Pictographs are often used in writing and graphic systems in which the characters are to a considerable extent pictorial in appearance. A pictogram may also be used in subjects such as leisure, tourism, and geography.

pictogramChart.title: When?
content: Pictograms can come in handy quite often when visualizing data in infographics, reports, presentations.
You can use a pictogram whenever you want to make simple data more visually interesting, more memorable, or more engaging.

pictogramChart.title: How?
content: It can be used to present values such as ratings or scores. However, to visualize it in a good way, you need to make sure the icon is simple and meaningful. Remember the icons you choose should be relevent to the subject matter of your data.
Stick with rows of 5 or 10 icons for maximum readability, it is intuitive enough to count the number of data by counting the rows of the icons.
